text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] be a [mathjaxinline]4\times 3[/mathjaxinline] matrix. Suppose that the equation [mathjaxinline]Ax = v[/mathjaxinline] is consistent. Must the equation [mathjaxinline]Ax = 4v[/mathjaxinline] be consistent?

font.p: We can show it with algebra. Suppose [mathjaxinline]y[/mathjaxinline] is a solution to the equation [mathjaxinline]Ax = v[/mathjaxinline]. Then [mathjaxinline]Ay = v[/mathjaxinline], so [mathjaxinline]4Ay = 4v[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]A (4y) = 4v.[/mathjaxinline] Thus [mathjaxinline]4y[/mathjaxinline] is a solution to the equation [mathjaxinline]Ax = 4v[/mathjaxinline].

Intuitively, if we can produce [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline] by linear combination of the columns of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline], we can simply scale the weights of the linear combination to produce any scaling [mathjaxinline]cv[/mathjaxinline] of [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline].
